greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number with exactly n representations as a sum of 6 nonzero squares or 0 if no such number exists.
link: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Square Number
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
example: a(1) = 6 because 6 is the smallest number with exactly 1 representation as a sum of 6 nonzero squares: 6 = 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2;
a(2) = 21 because 21 is the smallest number with exactly 2 representations as a sum of 6 nonzero squares: 21 = 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2 + 4^2 = 1^2 + 2^2 + 2^2 + 2^2 + 2^2 + 2^2, etc.
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 20 2017
